captions.text: (Intro Music)

(Title)
Gemma's Bigger Bolder Baking Homemade OREO

Hi Bold Bakers! I use OREO in a lot of my
recipes. Most recently cookies and cream No

Machine Ice Cream. So I thought what better
idea than to show you guys how to make Homemade

OREO from scratch. And stay tuned to the very
end of this video where I will announce the

winner of the ice cream tub and scoop. So
let's get baking!

The OREO cookie dough is really simple to
make. You can either make it by hand or make

it with a food processor. I like to make it
with a food processor because it's really
fast.

Into your food processor add in your flour
dutch process cocoa powder

caster sugar
baking soda which gives those lovely crinkles

on top
a little bit of baking powder
and the always important salt.

Before we add any other ingredient we want
to mix up all our dry ingredients together
really fast to combine them. Lovely!

To this mix we're going to add the cubed butter.
Then back on with the lid and we're going

to pulse it until it resembles fine bread
crumbs. If you're doing this by hand you can

use your fingers or a fork to blend in the
butter. Now to bring this mix together we

add one beaten egg. Then back on with the
lid and we're going to pulse again until it
forms a dough.

That took around ten seconds to come together
and then you have your beautiful OREO dough.
Oh, it smells so good!

That's how fast and easy this dough is so
let's get them onto the baking tray and into
the oven.

To shape your OREO cookies I like to do a
very generous heaped teaspoon of dough. Give

each cookie a lot of space because it does
spread out while baking. And then just pat

down each cookie a little bit to make the
top kind of flat.

If you have time, I like to chill my dough
before I bake it so around 20 minutes in the
fridge does it the world of good.

We're going to bake OREO cookies off at 350
degrees F and almost as fast as they were

to make they only take 9 minutes to bake.
So it doesn't get much better than that.

While your cookies are baking, it's the perfect
time to make your vanilla buttercream frosting

to fill your OREO. The recipe for this can
be found in the Cookie Cake video and I put
a link in the description below.

If you haven't already done so, now is a great
time to SUBSCRIBE. And for mobile and tablet
viewers, tap the link below.
Our timer went off so let's check on our OREO.

Our OREO are done and they look and smell
great. As they rest, they develop these beautiful

crinkles on top that make them look really
good. We're going to let these go totally
cold and then we can assemble them.

My homemade OREO taste just like OREO but
they're a little bit softer in texture which
makes them a little bit chewier.

To assemble your cookie, generously pipe your
buttercream all around the edges. And if you

like your OREO double stuffed like I do then
keep on piping. It's a homemade dream come
true for OREO lovers.

If you want to try something really BIG & BOLD,
you can make Mint OREO. Add natural peppermint

flavor a tiny bit of green food coloring to
get your desired color. You can make a variety
of flavors!

And make sure to enjoy your OREO Cookies with
milk!
Mmmm. Even better than the real thing.

Thank you all for your great suggestions on
Ice Cream Cookie Sandwich. I loved reading

them. But there can only be one winner for
this competition. Nadz suggested Meringue

cookies with lemon curd ice cream. Sounds
fantastic! So Nadz these are making their

way to England to you. Thanks so much for
watching and don't forget to SUBSCRIBE to

my channel. And I'll see you back here again
next Thursday for more Bigger Bolder Baking.

title: Homemade OREO Cookies Recipe: How to Make OREO from Scratch! - Gemma's Bigger Bolder Baking Ep. 26

comments.text:
Hi Gemma, I just adore your recipes but, I've been wondering where do you 
get your ingredients? Your fruit looks so fresh and vibrant!﻿
comments.author: Lanatic xo

comments.text:
+Lanatic xo Thank you for your lovely comments. I'm fortunate to live in 
Southern California where we get great fruit year round. I try to buy most 
of my fruit in season from places like Whole Foods, Trader Joes, and 
Farmer's Markets. Good ingredients are the key to great baking. Don't skimp 
on things like good quality butter, flour, etc. :)
comments.author: Gemma Stafford

comments.text:
I was wondering do you have a website where you can get all these recipes 
that you have done on your YouTube channel?﻿
comments.author: Alexis Veal

comments.text: +Alexis Veal :)
comments.author: Gemma Stafford

comments.text: Ok thanks. I really like your videos you keep it short and to the point!
comments.author: Alexis Veal

comments.text:
+Alexis Veal It in progress right now Alexis. i know it is a pain to find 
the recipes but january we will have our website up and running :) do you 
know where to find the recipes ? he recipe can be found below the video on 
youtube. Click 'show more' and the recipe will be in that box at the 
bottom. Let me know if you can't find it. :)
comments.author: Gemma Stafford

comments.text: My name is Gemma!!!!!!﻿
comments.author: Gemma Cassama

comments.text: +Gemma Cassama aw yay, another Gemma :)
comments.author: Gemma Stafford

comments.text:
tried these today, and they are by far the most easyest cookies to make and 
are delicous! I halfed the recipie & added only 1/4 of sugar, but they were 
very chocolateley and WAAAAY better than oreos! thank yous o much for 
sharing this recipie with all of us on youtube! :D﻿
comments.author: DIY'S by yael

comments.text: your welcome! im looking forward to make more of your recipies!
comments.author: DIY'S by yael

comments.text:
+DIY'S by yael That is so great. I am really glad you liked the Oreo. I 
agree with you, they are such a great cookie. Onwards now to try more 
recipes :). Thanks so much for your lovely comment :)
comments.author: Gemma Stafford

comments.text: Marry me.﻿
comments.author: Seanorman88

comments.text:
You should! Believe it or not, Martha Stewart once did a special on Newfie 
food lol. I believe they can still be found on Youtube.
comments.author: Seanorman88

comments.text: thanks +Seanorman88 , I'll definitely look them up :)
comments.author: Gemma Stafford

comments.text:
+Gemma Stafford It's definitely mixed. Newfoundland was descended over time 
by many different European settlers. Ireland is our main descendant, but 
England and Scotland aren't far behind (amongst many others). In fact, our 
province is the first settlement in ALL of North America, and our capital 
city is the oldest city in North America. Our island has HUNDREDS of 
communities (or towns), which mostly all have distinct dialects, due to our 
mixed European heritage.
We also have our own culture of food. You should look up "Jiggs Dinner" and 
"toutons" for some simple, yet delicious food heritage.
comments.author: Seanorman88

comments.text:
+Seanorman88 I have heard that accent because I saw a documentary on 
Newfoundland and I heard loads of irish accents. It's a little mixed but 
definitely Irish which I think it's what mine sounds like now :)
comments.author: Gemma Stafford

comments.text: +Seanorman88 lol, I'm from Ireland :)
comments.author: Gemma Stafford

comments.text:
+Gemma Stafford Husband shmusband lol. I kid.
In all seriousness though, what is that accent? Irish? I live on an island 
in Canada called Newfoundland, which is of mostly Irish descent. Our accent 
is very similar to yours.
comments.author: Seanorman88

comments.text: +Seanorman88  I'll check with my husband :)
comments.author: Gemma Stafford
